Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
On 3/03/21, youth sexually assaulted another youth at facility by attempting to pull
down youth's pants and touch youth's penis. The following day, youth got on top of
youth in the hallway once more and was attempting to bite youth's penis. Youth were
separated after the second incident.
INVESTIGATION:
The full complaint that was received reads as follows:
On the night of 04/03/2021, Resident A sexually assaulted Resident
B. Resident A attempted to pull down Resident B's pants and touch his private
(meaning penis). The next day Resident A was in his bedroom and Resident B
was in the hallway near Resident A's bedroom. Resident A snuck out of his
bedroom into the hallway with Resident B, out of staff sight. Staff member came
down the hall to find Resident A getting off the top of Resident B. Resident A
was on top of Resident B and attempted to bite his private (meaning
penis). Resident A has been moved to a different unit and the boys are now
separated.
On 04/04/2021, Resident B came out of his room and went to staff member Staff
1 and told her the night before Resident A tried to pull down his pants and tried
to touch his privates, while in the hallway out of staff sight. Later Resident B got
mad and stormed down the hallway another peer went to go after Resident B,
however staff stopped the child. Resident B was found in the hallway with
Resident A. Resident A was in the process of getting off Resident B. Resident
A was supposed to be in his room. Resident A and Resident B were told to go
back to where staff are. Resident B then asked to talk to Staff 1 again.
Resident B told Staff 1 that the same thing happen however this time Resident A
was on top of him and tried to bite his privates (meaning penis). Resident A has
been moved to a different unit and the boys are now separated.
I interviewed Staff 3 by phone in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist on
4/7/2021. He reports not being aware of the allegations but did report that staff are
trained to keep residents in a “line-of-site” at all times. He also reports that is critical
if there are two residents in a hallway at the same time.
I interviewed Administrator 2 at the facility with the DHHS Specialist on
4/8/2021. She reports not being fully aware of the allegations but that she will

provide all requested documentation. She was given a list of required documentation
and she indicated it will be sent as soon as possible. She also reports that all staff
are trained to provide “line-of-site” when supervising residents. She stated, “if a
resident goes down a hallway, staff are trained to follow”. She reported that the
facility received a variance for staffing because of the difficulty in keeping staff during
the COVID-19 pandemic. She also reported that this variance involved a change in
the staffing ratio from 1:2 to 1:3 on the C unit through 4/6/21.
I interviewed Resident A at the facility with the DHHS Specialist on 4/8/2021.
He reports moving to B Unit a “couple of weeks” ago but was unable to identify the
reason for this move. He also reported that he began his stay at the facility on the B
Unit but was moved to the C Unit before being replaced to the B unit. He denied
doing any behaviors as indicated in the allegations and reported that he never
leaves his room at night with the exception to use the bathroom. He stated, “no kid
has touched me or tried to pull my pants down”. He also reported knowing Resident
B and described him as his “BFF” (best friend forever). He denied talking to Staff 1
about the allegations. He ended by reporting that staff are always watching the
residents and that he feels safe at the facility.
I interviewed Resident B at the facility with the DHHS Specialist on 4/8/2021.
Resident B reports that Resident A was “trying to do something I don’t like” and it
“happened in the morning and at night”. He also reported that Resident A “tried to do
the same thing both times” and both times it happened in the “same hallway, in the
back area”. He stated, “Resident A was already in the hallway and staff were in the
milieu area. Staff are supposed to be watching us all the time.” He reports that he
told Staff 1 right after both incidents occurred. He also reports that the first time
occurred “before and after bedtime” and the second time occurred the next day
“after lunch”. He reported that residents are not allowed in each other’s bedroom and
that he has never gone in another resident’s bedroom. He did report that residents
are allowed to leave their rooms after bedtime for “snacks or to use the bathroom”.
He ended by reporting that Resident A was moved from the C Unit after the incident
occurred and he now feels safe at the facility.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility with the DHHS Specialist on 4/8/2021. She
reports working on the C Unit when the second incident occurred and that she is
aware of the allegations. She also reported that Resident B told her that “Resident A
had grabbed his balls and other privates in the little hallway” the evening before. She
reported that Resident B told her that when the first incident occurred the evening
before, she had asked him where the staff were, and he told her that two of them
were “in the office with the door propped open”. She reported that Supervisor 1 and
Staff 2 were the staff working the evening the first incident was to have occurred.
She reported that the second incident occurred the next day while she was working
on the C Unit. She also reports that she didn’t see the incident occur. She described
the situation at the time the incident was to have occurred.
It was around 11:00 am and it was free time. The kids wanted to watch television

so I was hooking up the staff computer to the television so they could watch a
Disney+ movie. One of the kids was walking the halls and Resident B was
walking the loop. Resident A was in his room, but I didn’t see him come out of his
room. Staff 4 went down one hall, and I went down the other hall, but we never
saw what Resident B told me later had happened. We didn’t see what occurred
between Resident A and Resident B, but Resident C said that he saw it and he
told me that Resident A was holding Resident B down and trying to grab his
privates. All of this occurred within two minutes.
Staff 1 was asked about supervision of residents and she stated, “I don’t believe that
staff need to move to different locations as long as the kid is walking the halls.” She
also stated, “we have mirrors in the corners of the hallway”. She was asked about
Resident A being allowed to be in the bedroom in the back hallway and she stated, “I
think it was miscommunication between staff that allowed that to happen” because
Resident A has been sneaking lately”. She reports telling Administrator 1 that
Resident A should not be in that specific bedroom because of his behaviors towards
others. She also reported that a few days earlier Resident A had gotten a staff “in a
choke hold in the back hallway”. She reported the incident and Resident B’s account
to her supervisor who told her to complete an incident report. She was asked about
checking on a resident when they go to their room and she reports that staff will
check but are “not required to do a room check log unless they are sleeping”. She
ended by reporting that Resident A was moved to the B Unit sometime after her shift
ended that day.
I interviewed Administrator 1 at the facility with the DHHS Specialist on
4/8/2021. She reported being aware of the allegations and that the facility does not
have a written policy of staff keeping residents in a line-of-site. She also reported
that staff know they should have a line-of-site with residents and that the facility has
discussed “posting staff” at the end of the hallway involved in the allegations. She
admitted that staff were not providing the appropriate supervision which allowed the
incident to occur. Administrator 1 was asked about this specific room and she stated,
“we try to keep this room open because of its location”. She reported that Resident A
“manipulated his way into the room”. She also reported that there was
miscommunication and Resident A lied to staff “saying he had permission” to use the
bedroom.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility with the DHHS Specialist on 4/8/2021. He
reports working on C unit the night that the first incident is alleged to have occurred.
He also reports knowing nothing about the incident. He reported that there were two
staff for five kids that shift (2:30-10:00 pm). He also reported that the residents like to
“gather in the back hallway” but that he is “always getting the kids away from the
hallway”. He gave the same report about line-of-site supervision as Administrator 1.
I interviewed Resident C at the facility with the DHHS Specialist on 4/8/2021.
He reported “I don’t want to talk about it, I told Staff 1 about it already”. Although he
refused to talk about the incident, he did report that it took place in the hallway and

Resident A has since been moved from the unit.
I interviewed Staff 4 by phone with the DHHS Specialist on 4/12/2021. She
reports “knowing about the allegations”, and that she was working on the C unit the
day the second allegations took place. She gave a similar report to Staff 1’s report of
the incident. She did report that she knew Resident A was in his room and only went
to check on the hallway when Resident C went into the hallway. She reported
knowing that Resident B was also in the hallway and she knew that they “can’t have
two kids in the hallway by themselves”. She also reported that Resident A was in the
process of sitting up and Resident B was laying on the floor when she observed
them in the hallway. Staff 4 was asked about her responsibility of supervision of
residents, and she reported, “no one ever taught us that we had to have line-of-site
on kids. We were never told that not having eyes on a kid was inappropriate”. She
also reported that she was never told that Resident A had issues with acting out.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 by phone with the DHHS Specialist on 4/12/2021.
She reports working on the C unit the night of the first allegations but not being
aware of the reported incident taking place. She did report that Resident A kept
coming out of his room and Resident B did walk a few laps during the shift. She also
reports that staff are required to watch Residents when they walk laps and staff will
position themselves so they can observe them at all times. She gave the same
report about being taught about line-of-site as did Administrator 1 and Staff 2. She
also reported that she will not allow a resident in the back hallway without
supervision.
Documents reviewed:
Personnel records of Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4, and Supervisor 1. I reviewed
personnel files of the four staff present at the time of the allegations. There is no
documented disciplinary action taken with these staff with the exception of Staff 4.
Documentation provided indicates that Staff 4 missed the “deadline date for annual
training completion”. This just occurred and the facility is in the process of
developing disciplinary action. The four staff have documentation of completing all of
the required trainings and orientation.
Policy/Procedures. I reviewed the Supervision policy/procedure for the facility.
They presented a policy tilted, “Staff to Resident Ratio”. This document focused
more on the ratios for staff and what actions staff must take when a resident is on a
1:1 ratio. This document also explains what actions staff must provide when the
resident is out of their line of site. This involved the random variable room checks
outlined in the licensing rules. At the time of the writing of this report, the facility has
provided the following document for the direct supervision of residents. This new
document is titled, “Resident Supervision Guideline”. This document states, “In the
milieu staff will have residents in their line of sight at all times.”
Incident reports. I reviewed the incident reports documented for the allegations.

The facility presented five incident reports which all documented the allegations
reported. Two of the incident reports reviewed were written by Staff 1 and three were
written by Staff 4. Four of the documents described the second incident outlined in
the allegations and one described the first incident. The descriptions matched their
interviews.
Functional Behavior Assessment. The behavioral assessment for Resident A was
reviewed and documentation outlined his functioning level, diagnosis, medication,
target behaviors, preventive strategies, responses to challenging behavior,
reinforcement, and justification for intrusive measures. The target behaviors section
identifies “physical aggression and maintaining the personal space of others” as
areas of concern.
Variance for staffing ratio. I reviewed the approval for the staffing ratio change and
it is documented in an email dated 3/25/21 from the Manager of the State foster care
program. The facility was granted the variance due to the difficulty of keeping staff
with the COVID-19 issue.
Team Meeting minutes. I reviewed several team meeting minutes starting on
8/4/20 and ending on 2/25/21. This documentation does not list the staff present until
1/5/21 at which point they list the different staff for each unit. Staff 1 was not part of
the facility during this time frame and Staff 4 is documented as attending team
meetings on 1/5/21 to 1/7/21. The staff meeting minutes do document the need for
direct supervision of Resident A beginning on 1/5/21 and it is also documented
during this meeting that all staff need to have “eyes on at all times”. There is no
other documentation of supervision being a topic of discussion during these team
meetings.
Safety Plans for Resident A and Resident B. I reviewed the safety plans the
facility developed for the two residents involved in the allegations. Each youth has a
specific safety plan designed for their individual needs. The first part of each safety
plan addresses staff’s responsibility for supervision and what aspects of supervision
are expected of them. The second aspect of the plan is “staff documentation and
communication” which indicates the pattern of communication, so all staff are aware
of the issues and level of supervision required. The third aspect of the plans is the
“treatment” of each resident. This involves “areas being addressed, triggers,
precursors, and calming techniques. The fourth aspect involves “staff interventions
for escalated behaviors.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Evidence provided through interviews and written
documentation do support the allegations of staff not providing
the appropriate level of supervision for residents in their care. By
staff’s report there was approximately 2 to 3 minutes of
unsupervised time for Resident A and Resident B in the back
hallway in which the incident took place. Both staff present at
this time did not present as understanding the importance of
eyes on and line-of-site as primary supervision conditions. Other
staff interviewed did report that this area of the unit must be
monitored and have a staff present whenever a resident goes to
the area.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The facility should develop strong documentation and training
materials for staff in the area of supervision of residents. There
should be a refresher course of supervision on a regular basis
and supervision should be a topic at all staff meetings. The
administration should promote an environment of line-of-site
with a focus of treatment rather than just being present for all
staff. Staff should have a clear understanding of the needs of
the residents and the issues that they could present.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2019C0223060 dated 9/3/2019 with an approved CAP on
